title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #110: Chromatic Number Growth in Uncountable Graphs**

Conjecture: For ℵ₁-chromatic graphs, there exists F(n) bounding the size of n-chromatic subgraphs.

**Answer**: NO - DISPROVED by Lambie-Hanson (2020) in ZFC.

Key result: No such function F exists, even for uncountable chromatic number.

title: Graph
content:
A **simple graph** on vertex type V is a symmetric, irreflexive adjacency relation.

This is Mathlib's `SimpleGraph V` type.

title: Proper Coloring
content:
A **proper k-coloring** assigns colors 1..k to vertices so adjacent vertices have different colors.

Formally: c : V → Fin k with G.Adj v w → c v ≠ c w.

title: k-Colorable
content:
A graph is **k-colorable** if it admits a proper k-coloring.

This is the fundamental concept in chromatic graph theory.

title: Chromatic Number
content:
The **chromatic number** χ(G) is the minimum k for which G is k-colorable.

For infinite graphs, this can be an infinite cardinal (ℵ₀, ℵ₁, ...).

title: Induced Subgraph
content:
The **induced subgraph** on S ⊆ V contains all edges of G between vertices in S.

This is the natural restriction of G to a subset of vertices.

title: Finite n-Chromatic Subgraph
content:
**HasFiniteNChromaticSubgraph(G, n, bound)**: G has an n-chromatic subgraph on at most `bound` vertices.

The conjecture asks if `bound = F(n)` exists uniformly.

title: Aleph-0 (ℵ₀)
content:
**ℵ₀** (aleph-null) is the cardinality of the natural numbers.

It's the smallest infinite cardinal.

title: Aleph-1 (ℵ₁)
content:
**ℵ₁** (aleph-one) is the first uncountable cardinal.

ℵ₁ = succ(ℵ₀), the successor of aleph-null.

title: Cardinal Chromatic Number
content:
**HasChromaticNumber(G, κ)**: G has chromatic number exactly the cardinal κ.

For ℵ₁: not k-colorable for any finite k, but 'ℵ₁-colorable' in a suitable sense.

title: de Bruijn-Erdős Theorem
content:
**de Bruijn-Erdős Theorem (1951)**:

If χ(G) = ∞, then for every n, G contains a finite n-chromatic subgraph.

**Crucial limitation**: This says nothing about the SIZE of such subgraphs!

title: Erdős-Hajnal-Szemerédi Conjecture
content:
**Conjecture (1982)**: For ℵ₁-chromatic graphs, there exists F : ℕ → ℕ such that for large n, an n-chromatic subgraph exists on ≤ F(n) vertices.

**Status**: DISPROVED by Lambie-Hanson (2020).

title: Conjecture Fails for ℵ₀
content:
The conjecture **already fails for ℵ₀-chromatic graphs**.

This was known before Erdős-Hajnal-Szemerédi conjectured it might hold for ℵ₁.

title: Shelah's Consistency Result
content:
**Shelah's Theorem (2005)**:

It is **consistent with ZFC** that no such F exists.

This left open: is it provable in ZFC, or just consistent?

title: Lambie-Hanson's ZFC Disproof
content:
**Lambie-Hanson Theorem (2020)**:

The conjecture is FALSE **in ZFC** (no extra assumptions).

Constructed an ℵ₁-chromatic graph defeating every proposed F.

title: Conjecture Disproved
content:
**Theorem**: ¬ErdosHajnalSzemerediConjecture

The conjecture is FALSE. Proof: apply Lambie-Hanson's counterexample.

title: Tower Function
content:
**tower(k, n)** = 2^2^...^n with k iterations.

Erdős expected F would grow faster than any tower function. Moot: F doesn't exist!

title: Lambie-Hanson Graph Structure
content:
**LambieHansonGraph** structure:

1. χ(G) = ℵ₁ exactly
2. Defeats all proposed bounds F
3. Still has n-chromatic subgraphs (de Bruijn-Erdős)

The graph exists by Lambie-Hanson's construction.

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #110: DISPROVED**

The Erdős-Hajnal-Szemerédi conjecture is FALSE.

- Shelah (2005): Consistent with ZFC that no F exists
- Lambie-Hanson (2020): Proved in ZFC that no F exists

de Bruijn-Erdős guarantees existence but not uniform bounds.

title: The Answer
content:
**Answer**: NO

Disproved by Lambie-Hanson (2020) in ZFC.

No uniform bound F(n) exists for ℵ₁-chromatic graphs.
